response.answer_text: It is a complex topic, but it is not a mental illness. Therapy is generally not helpful and often harmful when the goal is change of preference. Theories about causation of homosexuality have changed enormously over the last forty years. When I was in training, the explanation was that there might be some biological contribution but the psychological etiology was important. Male homosexuality was attributed to an immaturity--a failure to successfully negotiate certain developmental tasks--i.e. to satisfactorily resolve the Oedipus complex with his father, so that women could be seen as the main love object. A similar path with was described for women--giving up mother to see men as the main love object. Confused?  Well, when you observe little children, they do love the parent of the opposite sex fiercely. This is around ages 3-5. Does this behavior, though, define sexual preference? Children who grow up to be homosexuals also go through this triangular drama--and if this was the sole cause, you would expect that they would show opposite gender preference from toddler-hood on, and they don't.  Bisexuals were said to have poor "object constancy," which is the ability or inability to hold a picture of an object in your mind. An example of this would be how when a woman thinks of romance, she sees a man in her mind's eye--her imagination. She equates love with men. A bisexual woman might see a man or she might see a woman. Love doesn't have a specific gender for her.  2 year olds don't have object constancy. "The blanket game" is a way to show this. Mother and 2 year old are playing. Then mother puts a blanket over her head and "disappears." The baby cries. She doesn't know that mother still exists under the blanket. Fast forward one year. The baby has developed to a point where she knows that although she can't see mother, mother is still there, just hidden by the blanket. People with a lack of object constancy experience the temporary absence of something as a permanent disappearance. A 2 year old will experience that with everything. Adults who have certain kinds of issues (abandonment, abuse by one gender or the other)will have poor object constancy with objects related to the traumatic experience.  A bisexual then would theoretically be unable (in her mind's eye) to psychologically remember that men exist as love objects when she sees a desirable woman.  This, though, doesn't necessarily explain sexual preference. Is it mental illness if a woman (say) likes men, but occasionally likes women, too? There may be an explanation for this, but it is not mental illness.  There is another interesting phenomenon called "fluidity" occurring more commonly in lesbians--which is a complete shift in preference from one gender to another. Usually, the shift occurs once. There's no conscious thought about making the change.  As homosexuality was described more clearly, it became clearer that even when a feeling was explained adequately by a psychological theory,  there was no proof that the feeling led to a given behavior. As psychological explanations were viewed with more suspicion, homosexuality was then thought to have been caused by "biological factors."  Whatever those were.  There was also loose talk about genetics. It became important that no one feel blamed, sick or unhappy.  Then the human genome was mapped and it was found that there are no genes for homosexuality. None.  "Biology" was lost as one of the murky reasons why people are homosexual.  Then the psychological theories got a work-over--male homosexuals were believed to want a loving father figure because their own father was absent, abusive or non-loving.  Lesbians loved women because their mothers were the only safe people to love. But how does this explain lesbianism in a woman who has a great relationship with her father, and maybe even her mother, too? How does this explain a male homosexual who feels loved and respected by his father, who is also a great guy?  The next explanation makes me feel a little crazy. Homosexuality is now said to be due to "epigenetics," which could loosely trace back to environment, or family or psychology. A nasty vicious circle--especially if you are looking for a reason to discriminate against, or condone violence against homosexuals.  Homosexuality is a variant of heterosexuality. You can say it the other way, too: heterosexuality is a variant of homosexuality. It is limiting and probably wrong to label one the "normal" way and the other the "abnormal" way. It is fiercely unpopular to question the normalcy of heterosexuality, these days, ironically, given the history of discrimination against homosexuals. But that has also made it fiercely unpopular to question, hypothesize or do research on causes of homosexuality. Historically, theories about homosexuality have been used to condone discrimination or mistreatment.  So even if  such research could be funded, at this point, any theories could be construed as a reason to deprive homosexuals of their rights. Cause could be equated with abnormality.  So can such research ever be done? Probably not for awhile. The history of violence and discrimination against homosexuals is too recent. Some forms of prejudice are still present.  Lots of people equate it to a sin against God. So we may not find out for quite awhile what causes homosexuality--or for that matter, heterosexuality.

This is a complex topic. Before 1973, homosexuality actually was considered a "mental illness", at least by the psychiatrists that authored edition 2 of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-II).  In edition 3, it was reclassified as normal, see: When Homosexuality Came Out (of the DSM) - Mad In America But just because a phenomenon is considered by some to be a "mental illness" doesn't mean it actually is.  Even the very notion of mental illness is controversial.  There are behavioral patterns, psychological makeups, and syndromes that may or may not be in alignment with the dominant social norms of the day, and when a behavior deviates sufficiently far from what people with "authority" think is common, then someone somewhere labels the behavior deviant, or an illness. As one psychiatrist quipped, what might be considered obsessive-compulsive disorder in America today, might be seen as a healthy desire to maintain a spotless home in, say, Germany or Japan. The definition of "mental illness" that is emerging in the mental health field today focuses on whether a behavior pattern is dysfunctional or not. If someone is not having a problem getting along in the world, then there is no illness. In the 1600s, there were "witch hunts" in which women, identified by their "bizarre" behavior, were ostracized and killed. Their behavior was "dysfunctional" in the sense that it led to their ostracism from society, however this "dysfunction" was entirely manufactured by society and the women were the unwitting victim. So even with "functional" as a definition of illness, one needs to be cautious in defining which problems are the result of the individual and which are ultimately the fault of a society that is being rigid and judgmental. As recently as 1980, "hysteria" was classified as a mental disorder affecting only women until it was deleted from the DSM. For homosexuality specifically, the main arguments for it being an "illness" are: some rationale about procreationthe trouble it can cause people in their lives due to non-acceptanceits arguably low frequency (less than 10% of society)The main flaws in the "mental illness" claims are that: people with this "condition" lead happy successful liveshomosexuality has been a phenomenon for as long as recorded historyit seems to have a biological basis (from studies on rodents) and is present in other species.its arguably high frequency (as much as 10% of society)Ultimately, the concept of a "mental illness" is a new and constantly evolving idea, and it's not clear why homosexuality should be treated differently from any other sexual preference (e.g. blonds vs. brunettes). If the importance of procreation were really the dominant argument, then celibate priests and people not wanting children could be considered sexually deviant as well.

Today it is not classified as a mental illness. The biggest reason it is not classified is due to wanting to rid the stigma associated with being LGBTQ. When you label someone with a mental illness society has a tendency to treat people less favorable. In their reevaluation of homosexuality, they realized that most of the mental health components associated with homosexuality had more to do with how the world treated them, and how they saw themselves rather than the actual sexual identity. In the 1970s they officially removed it in the DSM. With this being said, there are still many psychologist and psychiatrist that still believe there is a mental/emotional aspect in the development of homosexuality. There seems to be a strong environmental correlation to it’s onset, with a higher than average amount of individuals coming from abusive families where sexual abuse occurred in childhood. Although not scientific, my own personal sampling of close friends/family in the LGBTQ community seem to also agree with these statistics. 6 out of 10 have related having been sexually abused or had emotionally abusive fathers. So although there is not a clinical diagnosis today for homosexuality, I do believe there is support in literature and in practice that homosexuality may be a result of some sort of childhood trauma that causes an individual to have a subconscious fear of the sex that hurt them (more in Lesbians) or as in other mental illness like eating disorders, or sadomachosistic behavior, there is a need to regain a sense of control. But these of course are just theories. Psychology is not an exact science. If you don’t like one theory, just move on to the next one.

I might define mental illness differently to others. I define it as when something is not working as it should, and requires a medical intervention to help it to work properly. For example, if you drink a bottle of whiskey you have a real chemical imbalance in your brain. You can’t walk straight, think straight, and your liver may not forgive you, but you are not considered to have an illness, everything is working as it should given the circumstances. If someone has a phobia of spiders, it is a way of thinking and feeling about something that is perfectly understandable. If you look at that fear you will probably find the reason for it and be able to resolve that to peaceful and calm. This does work: a friend of mine tells me that they stared at the big spider thinking, “this is interesting we have never been here before what am I supposed to do with you now I’m not afraid of you?” Is a phobia of spiders a mental illness, even though it can create an extreme, even hysterical reaction? As far as I know the brain is working perfectly well, memories are working ok, emotions are definitely in play. The reason for it can be identified and resolved. Most of what people think of as a mental illness, when analysed in detail, turns out to be perfectly understandable. It may not look rational to you, but if you had been through what they have been through, you would react in the same way. Therefore you cannot really designate something as a mental illness until you have looked at all known and understandable emotional issues. When you have resolved everything that has an explanation, only then can you suppose that what does not respond might be a genuine mental illness. Since there is not a single person currently on the planet that has resolved all of their emotional problems, it is very unlikely that you get to discount all understood causes. Looking at things this way, in 20 years as a therapist I have never seen an actual mental illness, other than that which has actually been caused by medications, ECT, brain-damage or dementia. With regard to homosexuality, its no different to hetrosexuality, everyone has emotional issues to work through, and I would encourage anyone to go deep to resolve any and every negative emotion that they have. Every anxiety, every worry, insecurity, feelings of rejection, and so on; we all need lots of work. What I would like to say though, is that I have met some gay guys, who had issues which have a profound effect on how they feel about themselves and their relationships, and their feelings changed as they had therapy for those issues. Some of those issues led guys to think that they were gay, even though they themselves later realised that they weren’t. It does happen. I have also met a couple of people with DID/MPD who had some gay personalities and some straight ones, although they are technically the same person in different states of amnesia. Therefore, I don’t think that anyone should put a label on themselves, at least until they have made sure that all of the negative nurture influences have been resolved. You, me, every person owes it to themselves to find out who they really are, not who their parents dressed them up to be, not who their fears tell them to be, their peers, their neediness, or pain. Especially since all of those negative things can be resolved, they shouldnt be allowed to define who anyone is. Designating something as a mental illness basically an attempt to label, categorise, and prejudicially relate to the label, rather than relating to the person, as, you know, a person. Don’t do that, it doesnt help anyone.

No. I just taught a class of college students about this.   The reason it's not is not just about stigma and acceptance.  Panic Disorder is a mental health diagnosis, and yet we should not think that people with panic disorder are bad.  We can accept both gays and people with OCD, but only OCD is a mental illness.  Part of the reason for this is that OCD can have a negative impact on your daily functioning and involve emotional distress.  Question I challenged my college students with:  Homosexuality can, for some, be associated with anxiety, depression, and other distress, and can even lead to lifestyle problems like interpersonal conflicts, so why isn't it a mental disorder like other mind-body conditions associated with mental distress? Answer my students had trouble finding, because they were focused on the acceptance issue: Homosexuality, though associated with distress for some, is not a mental disorder because the distress is not caused by homosexuality itself, it's caused by the contrast between one's sexuality and society:  discriminative policies, bigoted attitudes, and internalized shame and confusion.  I hope we don't assume that calling a condition a mental illness means that we're saying that it's morally wrong.  Does classifying Gambling Addiction as a mental disorder lead to anti-gambler actions?  People creating diagnoses are not the cause of stigma and bigotry. The bigotry was already there, and the bigotry is the real problem, and that's the clinical reason that homosexuality is not itself the cause of distress or dysfunction and thus is not a mental or behavioral disorder.  One final way to frame the point I'm making; the purpose of labeling something as a mental disorder is to suggest a focus for treatment.  Gambling addiction was added to the DSM not because gamblers are bad, but to say that some problem gamblers need addiction treatment, and to define how we can tell it's gotten to that point.   Homosexuality is not a condition that needs to be cured or treated.
